clinical_study.brief_title: Electrical Activity of Diaphragm as a Means to Predict Extubation Success in Preterm Infants
clinical_study.official_title: A Prospective Study of Diaphragmatic Electrical Activity in Very Low Birth Weight (VLBW) Infants as a Means to Predict Extubation Success

brief_summary.textblock:
Mechanical ventilation used to support the sick newborn infant is associated with many complications including the development of chronic lung disease. Limiting prolonged invasive ventilation remains an important strategy to decrease lung injury and prevent chronic lung disease. Currently, there is no objective measure available to predict readiness for removal of the endotracheal tube ("extubation") and discontinuing mechanical ventilation in this fragile population.
The investigators propose to predict extubation success by evaluating the electrical activity of the diaphragm (Edi), which provides important information about the "drive" to breathing coming from the brain and the function of the diaphragm, two essential factors determining extubation readiness and success.

detailed_description.textblock:
In this observational study, very low birth weight preterm infants with RDS who require mechanical ventilation in first 24 hour of life will be recruited. A size appropriate nasogastric tube with multiple array of electrodes (Edi catheter) will be inserted in each eligible infant. The average EdI (Edi_avg) and maximum Edi with breath occlusion (Edi_max) will be measured during mechanical ventilation just before extubation and then up to 3 days after extubation. All infants will be extubated to non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV or CPAP) delivered through nasal cannula
The specific aim is to determine whether there is a relationship between measures of Edi (Edi_avg and Edi_max with breath occlusion) taken just before extubation and the extubation success in a sample of preterm infants with respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). We hypothesize that Edi-avg and Edi-max of infants with successful extubation will be significantly different from the infants who fail extubation

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Cohort, Time Perspective: Prospective

primary_outcome.measure: Edi_avg just prior to extubation in infants with extubation success and those with extubation failure, AND Edi_ max just prior to extubation in infants with extubation success and those with extubation failure
primary_outcome.time_frame: From time of initial intubation to 3 days after extubation from mechanical ventilator
primary_outcome.description: Edi_avg and Edi_max with breath occlusion measured just prior to extubation will be compared between the group with successful extubation and those with failed extubation( i.e.needing re-intubation within 3 days of extubation)

secondary_outcome.measure: Study the trends of Edi_avg and Edi_max in preterm infants with respiratory distress syndrome during mechanical ventilation.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: From time of intubation on first day of life till extubation (or a maximum of seven days)
secondary_outcome.description: Edi_avg will be recorded continuously during mechanical ventilation to a maximum of seven day. We hypothesize that Edi_avg would correlate with severity of respiratory distress ( measured by respiratory severity index, FiO2 X Mean airway pressure)

study_pop.textblock: A convenience sample of forty(40) very low birth weight ( VLBW, <1500gm at birth) preterm infants less than 35 week gestation admitted in the ICN with the need for intubation and mechanical ventilation for respiratory distress in the first 24 hours of life will be recruited for this study.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
VLBW preterm infants less than 35 week gestation, requiring intubation and mechanical ventilation for respiratory distress in the first 24 hours of life
Exclusion Criteria:
Infants with a non-intact esophagus (e.g tracheal-esophageal fistula or atresia), a non-functional diaphragm (e.g. phrenic nerve palsy), severe intracranial hemorrhage or structural CNS abnormality, severe birth asphyxia and critically sick infant needing paralysis or deep sedation.
